So much weirdness going on in this beer. Is it an IPA? A black IPA? A coffee stout? An unholy bastardization of all three? I¬ím saying yes to all, since the various notes hitting your tongue with each sip makes every style seem reasonable. Massive coffee stout nose, chocolate and java, yet with an unexpectedly strong citric-pine undercurrent. Pour is amazing, deep rich black with a massive brown head and endless lacing. Taste starts in stout territory, mocha backed by a firm bitterness, yet the IPA notes crank up almost immediately, bathing everything in a bright citrus hop oiliness. Keeps with the espresso notes, yet a deep caramel sweetness tinged with anise adds padding, while the hops stay both bright and green and assertive. Finishes with a lengthy pinecone-in-my-coffee fade. Holy hell is this beer delicious. Perfect texture, silky smooth with just the right amount of carbonation to keep it floating between IPA and stout. I could drink this pint for years.

Bottle.  Pours black with a medium beige head.  Pine hop aroma with hints of roasted malts and chocolate.  Flavor of roasted/burnt malts and chocolate followed by pine/citrus hop flavors.  Bitter and slightly dry finish.

In short: A so-called Stout that is in fact an intensely bitter Black IPA with an overwhelming amount of green bitter hops.  For hopheads only (like me).
How: Bottle 500ml.  Consumed fresh one month after purchase (as fresh as a Mikkeller can be in North-America)
The look: Black body topped by a medium beige head with medium retention leaving a lot of lacings on the glass
In long: Nose is a explosion of fresh green hops with light notes of roast and chocolate.  Taste is more of the same.  I think there was chocolate malts, roast, an oat sensation, some booze, maybe a bit of toffee.  But as soon I took my first sip I could taste anything else than the hops.  Bitterness level is through the roof, probably in the top-10 most bitter beers I¬íve ever had.  This beer is a palate destroyer.  Hopping is very green, very fresh, like biting in green hop pellets.  The bitterness is intense enough that it adds to the alcohol bite and makes the beer appear more boozy than it is.  This is a straightforward beer but it¬ís hard for a beer to create complexity when the bitterness is so overwhelming.  I love Black IPAs and I¬ím a hophead so I enjoyed this beer, but I would only recommend this beer to extreme Black IPAs lovers.  This is rare hoppy beer that I¬íd like to taste with six more months of age on it.  Thankfully I had my Mikkeller long stem tulip glass to drink this beer, and I find it unbelievable that some people out don¬ít realize that the it tastes 25% better when a beer is served in its proper glassware and when a sandwich is cut diagonally.

11/08/2011 50cl @ Klaas¬í place (2011-378) Thanks to Klaas for sharing the bottle!
Dark brown to black beer, brown unstable head, non adhesive. Aroma: fruity hops, pineapple, citrus, mocha, roasted malts, caramel, bit sweet. MF: light carbon, medium to full body, bit syrupy texture. Taste: pretty bitter and hoppy start, citrus, fruity, pineapple, bitter. Aftertaste: hops, mocha, bit of coffee, caramel.

Bottle purchased at "The Village Beer Market" in Buffalo. Pours a dark, dark, dark, man this is dark beer. Huge tan head (about three fingers hight) that settles down to a thin layer, lots of spotty lacing here and there, and spots of residual sugar on the glass walls. Aroma is sweet and of fruit of the hop (LOL), but you then get that malty chocolate as well as coffee and some minor amounts of hops. Taste is fantastic, dark chocolate, oats, coffee, maltiness. Nice mouth feel, simply put its good stuff. I wanna try it for breakfast now.

Right down my alley with a steady strong bitterness of hops and dark chocolate mixed well with roasted malts.  It reminds me of Hoppin Frog DORIS with it¬ís heavy hop profile, but with a slightly thinner body.  Overall, an excellent, complex beer that gets much better as it warms.

Pours pitch black with a huge head that looks like coffee ice cream...amazing retention and lacing.  Aroma is extremely roasty with sweet dark chocolate, espresso, and maybe a hint of smoke?...subtle citrus.  Flavor is similar...so roasty!  Also some subtle but very resinous citrus at the end...floral!  Mouthfeel is slightly sticky and thick with a long dry roasted finish.  Very unique...so roasty but with an obvious very fresh hop flavor to balance it out...awesome.

Bottle, courtesy GT2. Pour is black with an impressive tan head, good lacing. Aroma is hops, chocolate, coffee. Taste is very hoppy with dark chocolate, bitter coffee. Actually quite nice. Palate is quite soft, bitter, easy to drink.

500mL. Probably should be moved to the Black IPA category. The pour is a deep brune looking black with a healthy, larger, tan head erupting with marshmallow creme density and large webby lacing. Nose is hop forward with apple cinnamon butter, pine, waxy dark chocolate, raspberry truffle, citrus bitters, noticeable grapefruit hoppiness. Taste is waxy dark chocolate, bitter cocoa, raspberry truffle. Palate is wickedly soft, medium to light bodied, with mild lactic tartness in the finish. Really nice.

Pour black with coffee brown head nice lace. Aroma huge citrus, pine, resiny hops, cocoa, roast, coffee, and chocolate WOW. Taste super roast, chocolate, coffee, quite bitter, citrus, resiny hops, pine, cocoa. MF medium to full creamy body nice carb. Wow ridiculously good probably a great benchmark for all Cascadian Darks outstanding.

Black  with a huge brown head. Very hoppy aroma, dominated by simcoe, if I¬ím not mistaking, roasted malts and coffee. The flavours are dry and bitter bordering on being harsh - but still highly enjoyable if you¬íre into a high dose of bitterness. I liked the original version better.

Bottle 50 cl. black with a large foamy brown head with good durability. Aroma is moderate to heavy malty, dark roast with roasted malt. notes of smoke is sensed. The taste seems at first a little heavy and sweet, but it turns out to be a nice well-hopped beer, which interact with the sweet tongue and makes a fantastic stout.
It could have been a disaster. Instead it is a decent imperial stout with some hop overtones.

500ml Bottle:  Aroma of coffee, hops, pine, light roasting, and a hint of citrus.  Poured pitch black in color with a small, brown head that diminished but lasted throughout as a film on top of the beer, as well as around the edges.  Opaque.  Sparkling.  Good lacing.  Flavor is lightly sweet and medium to heavily bitter.  Tastes of hops, pine, coffee, roasting, malt, light chocolate, char, and light marijuana.  Medium to full body.  Average carbonation.  Medium bitter, lightly sweet, hop, pine, malt, roast, char, coffee finish.  Nice and hoppy.  7.5%ABV is completely hidden throughout.

Pours to a pitch black body with a ridiculously creamy deep tan head with lots of lacing and coating.  The aroma is heavy on the oatmeal and chocolate with notes of oatmeal raisin cookies on the finish.  Perhaps some oatmeal sandwich cookies too.  Minor note of camphor.  The flavor had an oatmeal sandwich cookie up front and then was dominated by a dry chocolate stout.  Some green hops are there but are hard to detect amongst all the dry chocolate stoutiness.  Some bitter coffee.  The palate is medium bodied and pretty dry and bitter.

Very good dark-brown head over virtually black beer; lacerings. Very (USA) hoppy aromas, dry, mixed with roasted/nutty odours, well-balanced between the two; black coffee and moccha. Bitter coffee, chicory, slightly ashes and burnt starch in the finish. Only in the aftertaste, something less harsh, reminding of black chocolate, peppery. Rather well-bodied, slick but not viscous. Persistent head keeps adding variation in the MF. Good hoppy stout. As suggested, sampled as 11 o¬íclock breakfast.

Bottle.
Pitch black with a creamy, cappuccino to light brown head leaving lacing.
Aroma: roasted, chocolate, licorice, fruity hops, coffee.
Taste: heavily roasted, lakrisal/salmiak, chocolate, coffee, hoppy with citrus, grapefruit, floral notes, high bitterness. Long hoppy and bitter finish.
Very smooth mouthfeel.
Just a little bit harsh, but very tasty.

Bottle from josh. Pours black with a small dark tan head. Smells like hopped chocolate. Near full bodied. Thins as carb goes. Flavor is like really dark chocolate and very smooth burnt/toast malt. Finishing with the mouth thinking it has been savoring really dark chocolate. So the hop bitter must be making me think it¬ís really bitter chocolate. Pretty tasty stuff.
Bottle: very dark pour with a fluffy beige head and loads of lace. Roasted malt, cappuchino, some charcoal, herbal notes and piney hops.  A little astringent and lacking in the balance department
Pours black with tan head. Aromas of Oats coffee, and cocoa. Extremely hoppy with faint coffee notes on the palate. Nice brew

black with fluffy medium brown head.  Aroma is pine, sap hoppiness, slighter roast.  Flavor is a wonderful roast that is neither coffee-like nor roasted barley bitterness.  Hops kick in later.  Very good.

500 ml. bottle. Pours a thick,gradually collapsing mocha head, with copious lacing, over a nearly black (SRM 40) body.....nose is heavy coffee, lighter chocolate, light grass....taste is coffee, chocolate, toffee/caramel, finishing with an almost harsh, bitter, bite....mouth feel medium to heavy, slightly hot, carbonation makes a creamy texture. This is  very obviously a Stout. It is a bit unbalanced to the roasted coffee aromas and flavors. Additionally it is too hot on the finish. This is probably not the ABV, but rather some of the other ingredients. BJCP 7/3/13/4/7

Dark pour, but not the blackest stout ever. Beige head. Aroma is coffee, alcohol, hops. Taste is the same and very bitter. I couldn¬ít figure out where all the bitterness was coming from. Was the the coffee alcohol, or the hops? Actually tasted like it was higher than 7.5% abv. Body was medium for style. Good beer, but a little too bitter and hot to give it an elite rating.

Black pour wiht a tan head.  aroma is super earthy hop leaf, soil, chocolate, coffee grounds, pine needle.  Flavor is luscious chocolate nib, earthy, leafy hopping with an ultra dry, chalky, roasty finish.

Black pour, frothy tan head. Aroma holds fantastic notes of earthy hop, chocolate, coffee, pine, manure and tobacco. Really interesting and I dig it. Flavor is absolutely full of soil, grass and spruce, char and ash, oats, and baker¬ís chocolate. Absolutely love the dryness. The palate is surprisingly rich for an under 8% stout, but still awesome chalkiness and effervescence. I really really like this beer.

Courtesy of craftycarl21! The pour is dead black while the head is tan and creamy. The aroma is about as earthy as a beer can get. Earthen citrus hop, roasty espresso, manure-coffee, evergreen, and chocolate abound. The flavor holds huge chalky roast, cocoa nib, grassy evergreen soil, and coffee grounds. The palate is massively thick with creamy effervescence and a tannic barrel finish. Epic.
C: Pretty much opague black, just a slight bit of redness shining through. S: Lovely combination of coffee, chocolate, caramel and hops.T: Very, very hoppy and dark at the same time. Love it.
A very good beer. One of the best in Mikkellers beer geek series, perhaps overtaken by beer geek bacon. This obviously have a more hoppy flavour, which always is nice :-)

Bottle at home. Pours impenetrable black (what a surprise for a Mikkeller stout), no real head to speak of, weak lacing. Nose is gently hoppy, mostly of the pine variety, and dense, deep roast. Probing deeper I pick up notes of chicory, chocolate mousse, black coffee grounds, and hints of tar. Flavours of tar, spicy tight hops, and soap, creosote, and burnt toast. Very balanced, not as open as the Beer Geek Breakfast, but still quite nice.

500 ml bottle from Wine and Cheese Place. Pours a deep, dark brown color with a small tan head. Aroma of earthy, leafy hops, coffee, dark chocolate, roasted malts, and a bit of rubber. Flavor of really nice coffee and cocoa notes in balance with earthy and piney hops, with some citrus peel, and toast in the background. Medium-bodied, with a rich, robust mouthfeel and moderate carbonation. Really nice.

head: biege, creamy , thick , on the small side 
colour: black 
smell: ashes, high cacao sent, chocolat ( black) , hops, something sour, tiny bit of booze, charcoal , burned meat 
taste: start is bitter, irony, bloody , chocolat, cacao , coffee , ashy / smokey , heavly roasted malts, charcoal , bit of booze in the end herby , mouthtingling dryness with yeasty end , aftertaste is extremly grassy , not bad !

UPDATED: MAR 21, 2013 The style of this beer should be named india stout. I love both heavily hopped and heavily roasted beers, so this is perfect.

Pours a black beer with brown head with regular retention. The aroma has notes of citrusy hops, heavily roasted malts, cofee and caramel.

The flavor is excelent; as someone before me mentioned is like a black ipa with heavily roasted malts; is complex, the notes of citrus hops intensify and are well balanced by the roasted malt, cofee, chocolate and caramel notes. It has a medium to robust body and the alcohol is well hidden. 

If you are not a hophead, this beer is not for you, being that is a crossover between the stout and ipa styles.

This is indeed and outsanding beer i would by againg with no hesitation.

500mL bottle.  Poured very deep brown with a creamy, well-retained dark tan head.. looked great in the glass!  The aroma picked up a whole hefty dose of earth, fresh pine, and coffee roast over sweeter chocolates and more coffee.. quite hop forward.  The flavor led with pine and citrus bitterness, with dry-roasted coffee not far behind.. more coffee and burnt barley at the core.. piney bitterness and lesser coffee on the long, dry finish.  Medium-bodied, very bitter, and very roasty on the palate.. this was good, but I prefer the regular Breakfast.

UPDATED: JUL 20, 2013 Opaque, black color, beige light brown head, quite large. Smell hops, coffee, dark chocolate and raisins. Taste hops, coffee. Strong hopped stout. Medium to high carbo, very nice full body.

Bottle. Poured reddish black color with an average frothy brown head that was mostly lasting with good lacing. Solid roasted coffee and chocolate malt and earthy hop aroma. Medium to full body with a dry smooth texture and soft carbonation. Medium to heavy roasted balanced coffee and chocolate flavor with a heavy chocolate bittersweet finish of long duration. This is a standout beer.

500ml capped bottle.  Pours a viscous pitch black with a dense tan head on pour, but that dissipates fairly quickly to a loose film of a head and a solid ring around the edge.  Blast of coffee, patent malt, licorice, toasted brazilian nuts, and a dank sharp pineyness...smells like I would expect an dbipa would smell.  Chewy viscous body, carbonation isn¬ít super assertive or sharp, but it isn¬ít flabby or flat either. Semi sweet chocolate and coffee oatmeal stout up front, black patent malt takes over in the mid palate then the pineyness kicks in.  Finishes quite bitter with some licorice.  Not really cohesive or balanced.

Bottle. Dark blackish beer with a dark tan head. light malt and light pine aroma with light coffee. pine and grapefruit flavor with coffee and light toffee. Medium-plus bodied. Pine and grapefruit lingers with coffee and light chocolate.

500ml bottle, unknown date.  Served at cellar temperature.

Pours black with a large foamy and rocky brown head that takes forever to settle down and leaves clumpy lacing in its wake.

Aroma is like...well...a heavily-hopped coffee stout.  Heaps of premium coffee, chocolate, tons of roasted malts and a bit of smoke playing nicely with piney, grassy, citrusy hops.  While there is more hop presence than most other stouts, the coffee still steals the show.  Very good to great strength.

Flavor is very tasty premium coffee beans, roasted malts, chocolate up front then moves to a bitter hoppy finish featuring pine, spruce, and citrus.  A bit of sweetness with the coffee and hops teaming up for some good bitterness.  Some alcohol detected but what¬ís there is mild.

Mouthfeel is not quite medium, not quite full bodied, somewhat creamy, moderate carbonation.

Man, the hops really mingle nicely with this coffee stout.  Would classify well as a Black IPA.  Yet another tasty offering in the Beer Geek series and I¬ím glad to have had the chance to try (even if it was overpriced, even for a Mikkeller offering).

Sampled on 6/25/2011. This stout pours an eclipse black color from a 500ml bottle. Medium sized tan foamy head, nice retention and good lacing. The aroma is chocolate, coffee, hoppy and herbal. Medium bodied stout. The malts are chocolate, coffee, roasted malts and bitter. The hops are herbal and earthy. Decent carbonation. A lot of bitterness in this beer, first from the coffee, then from the roasted malts and then from the hops. There is a touch of sweetness that shows up every once in a while in the taste. This is a very coffee forward stout that¬ís been aggressively hopped. Yet kind of smooth and well balanced. Nice sipping beer. There is some alcohol presence even at 7.5%. Mouthfeel is full and round. Finish is clean and smooth. Aftertaste is bitter.

(bottle - 500 ml) Dark black pour with a thin and lasting tan head. Big hoppy aroma with some mild coffee underneath it. Bitter hops at the start that turns into a very nicely roasted coffee middle, but then goes back to a bitter hop finish. Almost like a very heavily roasted black IPA.

Bottle from Bacchanalia, Cambridge, 03.06.11 consumed with friend Trevor 17.06.11   Pours black with a beige head, this is a roasty and hoppy number with pine and citrus flavours combining surprisingly well with the roasty coffee flavours that provide the undercurrent to this beer. Good stuff.  A7 A4 T7 P4 Ov14  3.6

On tap at Cask Pub & Kitchen on 7th May 2011. Thick black with pale brown head and sporadic lacing. Sweetish malty aroma then BURST of delectable rich hoppiness and burnt malts. Rich coffee and grassy hoppiness transfer to a superbly intense rich finish that satisfies.

Bottle on sale at A Southern Season. Glad I picked this up. Pours thick black with a thin tan head appearing seconds after the pour but not sticking around in any substantial form for long. Nose is pungent green resiny hops, coffee and chocolate, and pleasant oatmeal/grain notes. This is a black IPA gone wild. Many brewers fail to mix these elements and just end up with a big, extreme beer that doesn¬ít taste that great, but everything in this beer is well integrated, and the whole transcends the parts. Full palate. Great beer.

500ml from sflpunk.
Appearance : Deep black with medium foamy and creamy brown head. Some lacing.

Aroma : Great roasted malt with light chocolate and coffee. Resinous and piny hops. 

Taste : Lots of hops with light roasted malt at first. Finish gets a bit more complex with light chocolate and coffee. Lots of piny and resinous hops. Quite a lot of alcohol too. Light rubbery notes.

Overall : Taste is a bit too hash for my taste. Nose is enjoyable. Alcohol is a bit too present. Not my thing at all.
Aroma is heavy hops; resin and citrus and coffee.  Taste is hugely hoppy with a nice roasted flavor.  Overall interesting good beer.
Great black ipa, doesn¬ít really taste like a stout. Good roasted flavors in the background

UPDATED: MAY 17, 2012 Bottle shared with friends at tasting.  Pours black with medium brown head.  Aroma is strong coffee and hops.  Flavour is coffee, chocolate, caramel, malt all with a lovely hop bitterness over the top.  Well balanced and with low carbonation.  A great beer.

50cl bottle pours an oily, opaque black with a brown, thin head.  Malty aroma, brown sugar, lightly hoppy, crackers.  Flavor is sweet, chocolate, a little citrus, a little vegetal, malty, toast.  Full bodied, sweet, lightly bitter finish.

Bottle shared by a friend. Black pour with small beige head now.  Aroma of hot, spicy hops and anise. Huge licorice drowns out the coffee. Bitter, boozy, and bold. Flavor of bitter, grassy hops, alcohol, tobacco, and burnt malts. Top hot. This should sit longer to get better if at all. Slick and oily

Le caf√©, le malt r√¥ti sont les principaux attraits. Je ne per√ßois pas le caract√®re du hops comme je l¬íaurais aim√©, le caf√© ralentit peut-√™tre ses ardeurs. Laissons tomber les attentes, excellente stout!

Pours dark black with nice fluffy caramel colored head from bottle.  Aroma has nice notes of green and pungent resin and pine, slight citrusy notes even, with a big coffee note with roast and chocolate in the background.  Taste is just as balanced as the aroma, with notes of some pine, resin, some caramel, coffee grounds, roast and bitter hops combine at the end to make a lasting finish.  Nice brew!

500ml bottle.

Pours pitch black and looks like all the other beer geek varietals sporting a thick tan head that recedes very slowly and leaves excellent lacing.

Aroma is definitely greener than the other versions with some fresh herbal hops on top of the regularly scheduled roasted chocolate malts and espresso beans.

The taste also starts with some citrus and pine bitterness which then flows into the bitterness provided by the heavily roasted malts and spent coffee grinds.  The finish is dry and bitter.

The mouthfeel is smooth as silk with strong carbonation and tingly throughout with equal parts coffee and hop bitterness.

Another nice installment from Mikkeller in the beer geek series with some fresh green hops adding some complexity to things.  I still like the original better though...

Bottle with Carla, Jade and Nathan. Pours an opaque black with dark brown foam. Smells roasty with hints of caramel, java, and hazelnuts. Tastes roasty with plenty of bitterness towards the end. Fells lightly creamy.

Delightful dry stout.  Hop was apparent in the early nose, along with coffee and biscuit.  Served at room temperature from a 16 oz bottle.  Appearance was jet black and a thick fine head that laced the glass nicely.  A thin layer of fine foam remained throughout. Taste was strongly hoppy at the outset, with the dry coffee and roasted malts following; but never any malty sweetness.  Finish was nutty and continued dry coffee; strongly bitter.  Body was medium/full, even when warm. Texture was creamy and well balanced.  Carbonization was moderate throughout.  This was an IPA in an Irish stout overcoat.  Nice.  Not my favorite style and therefore a bit more notable that it fared well in the review.

50cl bottle, BB 03/2012. Poured black with a thin brown head. Strong coffee aroma, also lots of hops and some cocoa. Flavor is very hoppy, more coffee and some chocolate even. Finish is very bitter, with a lingering instant coffee taste. When the beer got more warmer, I get too much burntness in flavor. Too intense, even though the finish was excellent.

Pours pitch black with a frothy tan head, big bubbles, semi thick lacing.  Big chocolate and coffee in the nose with a ton of roasted malt, it almost smells burnt.  Flavor starts with the deep roasted malt and deep notes of earthy, dirty hops.  Rounds out with a touch of caramel sweetness and finishes long and bitter.  Sticky, sticky, sticky, almost chewy.  Very good, essentially a hoppier and more bitter Beer Geerk Breakfast.

Bottle at slows bbq, Detroit.  Pours thick and black, strong hops on the nose.  Flavor is chocolate with a lingering hop finish.  Tastes like a young stout, which is the intended flavor, and is actually quite good.  Nice balance between the sweet chocolate malts and the strong hop presence.

Dark nearly black pour w/ a huge frothy well laced tan head.  First sniff was a floral a big floral hop w/ some hints of citrus, underneath that was a well roasted malt.  Palate had some nice viscocity, but lacked the thickness I like in a stout.  Some sweet hints of nuttiness that probably come from the oatmeal, a well roasted malt (lots of roast notes) and a pretty big grassy hopping.  A nice beer, but not one of my favs and not worth the price tag.

500ml bottle. Pours a dark brown with thin brown head that was quick to fade and scatter to the edge of the glass. The aroma first hits you with a citrus/pine dose of hops but then you pick up on the bitter chocolate and roasted coffee undertones. The flavor is pretty much the same. It reminds me of a dark chocolate covered espresso bean only instead of the coffee bean it is a hop cone. There is a great combination of bitterness from both the roasted malts and the hops that I enjoyed a ton. Fantastic brew that I plan to go buy more of.

500ml bottle from Sam¬ís, Durham. Body and appearance nicely sumptuous like the regular offerings, and here the dry, sharp, chalky quality of the brew is accentuated by the hops, giving it more of a mild bite on the palate and a tangy flavor. Glad to have given this one a shot, despite the sometimes forbidding price point of these Mikkellers.

Bottle. (Mikkeller rating number 50)

Dark brown with a small tan head.

Very interesting aroma and taste. Hops with the typical notes of a stout. Some kind of hybrid between a Black IPA and Stout. I liked the smooth and creamy mouth feel on this one. Nice beer!

Draught:
Small brown lacing in top of a black beer.
Smell hops, chocolate, hints of liquorice and spices.
Taste is like a mix of (imperial) stout and (imperial) ipa: hops, light liquorice, chocolate, light citrussy, spices, roasted malts, bitter.
Bitter hoppy and black ingredients aftertaste.
Low carbo, fuller body, soft tingly mouthfeel and light watery texture.
user_location: Best of E-Town mit 2 Brauhausen, NETHERLANDS

text: Shared 0.5l bottle. Pours a deep brown body with a solid tanned creamy head. Aroma is really grassy hops almost herbal-grassy with light green coffee beans, thin chocolate and roasted malts. Body is medium, texture oily to chewy and it¬ís medium+ carbonated. Flavors are strong coffee-filter, burned toast with a quite bitter hopy finish and a day old-coffee aftertaste, lives up to it¬ís name.

Bottle. Jet black body, big creamy caramel head. This is one good-looking stout! :-) Nose is roasty malt tones, tar, coffee, grassy hops. Subtle fruity undertows lingering just below the level where I can possibly ID them. Taste is coffee, bitter resinous hops and hints of roasted malts. Again, fruity hop tones come bubbling just beneath the surface. Long, bitter finish. A very good beer.

On tap at Cask Pub & Kitchen on 10 May 2011. Black with a generous beige head. Lovely roast aroma with strong coffee and chocolate notes. Joined by good, firm, resinous hops on the palate. Very rich but not at all sticky. Just have a very minor reservation that the elements didn¬ít quite fit together perfectly harmoniously. That¬ís just a tiny quibble though. Extremely tasty but a half was enough - I think I¬íd struggle to drink this any quantity.

Bottle.  Pours dark brown/black with a medium plus beige head.  The nose has big roasted malts, black coffee, resiny hops and a hint of citrus.  The flavor is similar to the nose, but works a little better for me.  The roasted malts, dark chocolate and black coffee work well with the green hops, citrus peel and resin.  Medium bodied, nice beer.

Bottle: Pours an oily opaque with a well-lacing froth of sticky light brown head.  Has a rich roasty piny hoppy nose with soft mocha notes.  Starts with good fullness and finely-dissolved carbonation with some lightly sweet roasted maltiness and lots of bitter coffee and hop flavor before a drier, heavily roasted finish.  Could use a little more sweetness for balance, but still a fairly unique and enjoyable brew.

Tap @ beer temple - rich black body, medium brown head. Aroma is more akin to an IPA whilst the taste brings you into imperial stout territory. The result of which is impressive, potent bitterness, both from malts and hops

Bottle @ home. Black appearance with a brown head that dissipates fairly quickly. Roasty dark chocolate malts, coffee, mildly piney hoppy nose. Piney hoppy bitter, dark chocolate malty, coffee flavor with a fairly bitter coffee hoppy finish.

Very dark brown I¬íd almost call it black. Thick chocolate brown crown floating on top. Grapefruit, hoppy coffee aroma, with a familiar aroma I can¬ít place or even name but I know I know it, you know what I mean, you know?  Burnt sugar and weird funk also is noticeable. This hop coffee combo is working for where others of this type have failed. Taste is just a mess, massive coffee hints of fruity citrus hops. A camp fire charcoal lingers forever in the after taste with a massive brutal bitter. I¬ím picking up a very odd sour flavor in the beer what would be easy to overlook unless you try hard to find it. beer is okayish¬Ö¬Ö¬Ö¬Ö¬Ö I can tell this is high quality but I¬ím not sure this is my cup of tea. I both like and dislike this beer its changing from sip to sip back and forth. The warmer the beer gets the more I like it the citrusy hops start to vanish and the bitter mellows with more of a chocolate coffee malt come on through. I guess I like it, maybe?, ya I like it.

Bottle. Pours with an opaque black body. Dark enough to eliminate any highlights on the edges. A massive, retentive, creamy brown head sits on top. Good lacing. Aromas are bready, malty, roasty, cookies, molasses, coffee with a large quantity of American hops. Citrus, orange, grapefruit qualities. Herbal. Lightly estery. Black pour with brown creamy head.  Aromas of chocolate and coffee.  Sweet caramel and chocolate malt, coffee, molasses, and vanilla.  very creamy texture.  A nice alternative to my morning shot of espresso.

UPDATED: MAY 21, 2011 Keg at BrewDog Edinburgh. Pour is "Mikkeller Black," with a good couple centimeters brown head. Smell is hops, something smoky, some coffee and a hint of sweet chocolate/vanilla. Taste is sweet to start, balanced by a massive bitterness. A really interesting beer, well-balanced and tasty.
UPDATED: bumped up the scores a bit, like this a lot.

Bottle. Poured that coffee soda dark black like most of this series.Nose is coffee, dark roasted malt with a Huge hop charector added.flavor follows that nose.  The hops truly intesify creating an additional bitterness to the huge finish of this. Quite delicious.

One of the prettiest beers I¬íve ever poured. Smells is staggering. Dark roasted malts, good hop backing, slight chocolate behind. Taste is bitter hops, coffee, roasted malt and some smoke flavor. Really good, my first Mikkeller, but not my last.

Tasty coffee-ish beer.  Very hoppy, above average mouthfeel.Bold taste.  Creamy mouthfeel, with above average head.
Liam¬ís bottle courtesy of Chris.
From a bottle,a hoppy stout,black, brown foam, medium bitterness, full body, average carbonation,a bitter Chocolate stout ,great stuff.

Bottle at Forgetfus Mikkeller Tasting poured a translucent dark brown with a lasting brown head. Aromas of pinme, grapefruit, grassiness, roasted malt, light coffee and light chocolate. Palate was medium bodied and smooth with a dry finish. Flavors of roastiness, pine, citruslight grassiness, light cocoa and a hint of coffe with a smooth dry lingering roasty bitter finish.

Bottle shared thx to rglk cons 2011-04-01 G√∂teborg
AR: hoppy, skunky, vanilla beans
AP: watery dark brown, 3 cm fluffy wee bubbly head
F: tart, watery, rubber - not my cup of tea

Bottle.  Very dark brown pour, almost black, with frothy tan head.  Roasted malt, light chocolate flavor, heavily roasted coffee-espresso, grapefruit, bitter pine, and slightly metallic hops.  A strong dark stout, with lots of hops.  Good, but I probably won¬ít drink it again.

Large snowdrift expresso/tan head.  Aroma is thin resinous pine, light roasted malt, and perhaps some chocolate although it¬ís hard to tell with the pine dominating.  Taste is roasted malt, oat, light chocolate, bitter coffee, and medium-level bitter hops and pine throughout.  Neutral, slightly watery feel in the mouth.  Extremely drinkable hop-forward stout.  I like it.

Huge notes of pine fill the air, along with roasted notes, slight coffee and chocolate.  

Poured black, with a big 3 finger mocha head, dissipated to a spongy film, leaving sticky, spongy lacing all the way down.  

The big pine notes are lot more balanced in the taste.  Though bold, they melt nicely with big chocolate and coffee notes.  The coffee bitterness blends well with the hop bitterness.  

The feel is nice and creamy, solid medium bodied, even a tad chewy.  Nice bit of substance for the style. 

Overall, I¬ím in love.  I adore hoppy stouts, and this is a shining example.  Kudos Mikkel.

Bottle.  Dark black pour, a little lasting lacing and a fresh coffee and black pepper aroma.  Flavor is also dirty bitter espresso, some lactose, vanilla sweetness and finished with a nice bitter bite.  Everything a coffee beer should be, I¬íd happily pay $11 for another bottle of this.

Bottle from Healthy Spirits. Pours jet black with a majestic light brown lacy head and a magnificent chocolate aroma. I hope this tastes as good as it looks and smells! Yes, it does. There is a delicious chocolate and coffee flavor with a smooth oatmeal texture that sticks to the palate, and a dry pleasantly bitter finish.

500mL bottle.  A jet-black pour with a thick & creamy mocha head.  Great balance in the aroma - lots of grapefruits, oranges, and citrus rinds along with freshly roasted coffee, dark chocolate, caramel, cream, pipe resin, and a distinct earthiness.  Medium body.  Light caramel upfront in the taste along with some dark chocolate.  A touch of cream in the middle.  A peppery finish with some harsh grapefruitiness and rye.  A drying finish that lingers.  There is a strange aftertaste of cigarettes.  Roasty all the way through.  Unique.
500ml, very oatmeal aroma, slight twinge of hops, very earthy on the backend, sweet and then earth. This is quite nice.

Gorgeous black pour with a big brown head.  Stuck around.  Big piney hops wafted from the glass out front, then a big coffee presence along with some roasty malt.  Flavors were big time hops, lots of pine.  This mixed well with the coffee and roast flavors of beer geek breakfast.  The finish was big time bitter.  The coffee bitterness mixed with the hop bitterness, made for a long lingering roasty bitter finish.  Mouthfeel was creamy, full, carbonation light.  Very nice.

bottle.  black with small brown head.  milk chocolate and green hops aroma.  flavors of graham cracker, dark chocolate, and hints of caramel.  palate is dry and quick.  medium body.  long roasty finish.

Bottle 500ml @ Zoney
Pours pitch black with a tan head. Aroma has notes of roasted malt, chocolate, coffee and citrus hops. Taste is medium sweet and medium bitter. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft.

Strong dark malts aroma dominated by the aroma underscored by hops and %. Not much foam on this one, nice lacing though, nice and dark. Thick sweet stout wih lots of bittering matched up with% at the end give the Mikkeller breakfast flavou I¬íve come to expect and enjoy. The coffee is noticably absent from this breakfast, but the stoit delivers.

Pours black with a thick brown head. Aroma is very strong it smells like a stout. rich and roasty. I smell coffee and chocolate. the hops are there. but the stout comes through very strong. Very bitter flavour. It is assaulting my palate. the flavour is so strong. The stout is very bold and complex and as you are enjoying the flavor of it all of a sudden. BAM!! bitter hops. It breaks the flavour and takes things over.  This beer is unbalanced and I am not enjoying it. They have ruined a good stout. Or they have made an over the top black IPA. Either way this beer does not work.

Same pitch black pour with large brown head as the regular Beer Geek Breakfast. The aroma is pure pungent hops - so strong that it¬ís hard to make out any other aromas. The hops continues on into the taste and mixes well with the bitter chocolate and roasted coffee flavours. This is less sweeter than the Beer Geek Breakfast and has a lovely citrusy-piney hoppy finish. When Mikkeller says "hop" he really means it! Really more like a Black IPA. Wonderful!

Bottle at Home.  Pours a near black body with a creamy coffee tan head that had nice lacing and sticks to the glass leaving behind a modest creamy ring.  Aromatically a beautiful marriage between fresh hop tones, roasted chocolate and bitter coffee roast.  Sweet and hoppy up front with a nice fresh cut grass y tone, followed by a lighter hoppy sweetness prickly pine, hints of citrus leaves you thirsty for more.  Rounds out a bit bitter with that roasted coffee bitterness but that even soon subsides to make room for that lingering grass y bittering hoppiness.  This is delicious, can hardly keep it in my glass.  Drink asap.

Bottle, shared with Parksy. Near black pour, low dense light brown head. Aroma is equally intense bitter roast and pine and pith hops. Flavours are the expected roasty coffee base layered over with piney hops--- tons of hops in fact! Hugely bitter finish. A chimeric blend of styles: part stout, part IPA. This could easily be re-categorized as a black IPA in my opinion. Very tasty.
user_location: the land of bitumen, beef & beer, Alberta, CANADA

text: Bottle via EZ liquors. Thanks Ant. Pours black with a thin tan head. Aroma is of citrus and pine hops, roast, chocolate and some coffee. Taste is complex with a nice mouthfeel, notes of coffee, chocolate, roast and a lot of lingering citrusy/pine hops in there on the finish. Very solid.

Very interesting taste. The coffee bitterness and the hop bitterness blend together to make it an interesting transition between the two flavors. The aroma is of hops and coffee. The appearance is very black with a brown head that has great retention. Good beer overall, However; I am looking forward to the beer geek brunch weasel more

Bottled. Quite much pitch black colour, small beigeish brown head. Aroma is hops, grass, liquorice, toffee and some maltyness. Flavour is liquorice, some bready and sweetish malts along with floral and grassy hops. Mild old black coffee as well as some burnt wet wooden notes as well.

black body with a huge medium mocha head, great retention, looks great... interesting nose with coffee with a very citrus hop finish... not a fan of this at all, the hops are too strong and citrusy and that does not go with the coffee at all, the coffee is also very bitter... heard some great things but disappointed here

500 ml bottle from EZ thanks to Dean. Poured a good looking pitch black body underneath an average sized tight foamy dark brown head. Aroma offresh hops, citrus, roastiness, oats, earhty. Smooth bodied with average carbonation, lingering toasty and bitter aftertaste, fuller bodied with an almost creamy feel. Flavor of coffee and citrus rind, grapefruit, earth, dark toast. Great beer highly impressed.

Tap at brewdog ... deep black ... thin tan head ... big coffee big sweet hop nose ... juicy roast malts ... light roast bitterness ... piney hop linger ... very nice and its meant to be hoppy ... but too hoppy a stout for me

Pours a dark brown color with a medium frothy mocha head.  Aroma is coffee, light chocolate, bitter and earthy hops.  Taste is much the same.  Nice smooth chocolate and coffee taste with the hop bitterness on the palate.  Still prefer the original version, though.

Poured black with a thin tan head.  Very hoppy aroma with chocolate and roasted malts.  Coffee as well with oatmeal.  Taste is quite roasted and hoppy at first with a little bit more bitterness than I would have liked.  Taste transitions into an oatmeal and chocolate finish with some coffee and dark fruit.  Some more malty sweetness would have been appreciated, overall it¬ís a little bit too hoppy and bitter.  It is very flavorful, however, so I really like it.

1 pint .9 fl oz bottle. This is really kind of like having breakfast with a bowl oatmeal and a cup of coffee, while replacing the OJ with an strong ipa. So much contrast of flavors on the malt to hop spectrum, yet somehow they blend together seamlessly to create both a rich and creamy yet piercingly bitter creation. The notes in the aroma may, not surprisingly, muddle together a bit though. Some strong, fresh brewed coffee, mixed cream and dark malts, full oaty grains, caramel and a mix of earth and fruity hop. Pours beautifully. Heavy, fluffy, cloud-like dark cream head, layers of lacing, wispy retention, a medium to thick body, mostly opaque, and sandy dark brown in color. As mentioned, the mouthfeel is both medium thick malted creamy and heavy bitter at the same time. My palate is both confused and really happy at the same time. Notes of oat, cream, caramel, earth, strong coffee, caramel, thick citrus, and light leafy hop. Not a bit of sugary sweetness here. The finish is sticky, bitter and lingers dark malted grain, coffee and tropical hops endlessly. I¬ím tempted to say I could do without the coffee in this, but I also fear things wouldn¬ít come together as well if is wasn¬ít there. Overall, this was a unique piece of fine beer making that takes you in all different directions. Great stuff.

A wonderful beer with an unusual taste. The pour is nearly pure opaque black with a hint of brown on the bottom edge. A two finger creamy tan head with a mixture of tiny and big bubbles. The aroma is very hop forward with an IPA-esque smell of grapefruit and tart citrus sweetness. The roasted malts and coffee are very forward as well with a sweet bitter coffee note. The body is medium with mild carbonation and overly dry. The middle is a citrus sweetness with an roasted coffee taste. Getting licorice and roasty notes. The hops are overbearing on the finish with a bitter grapefruit finish. Smooth taste, don¬ít notice the alcohol at all. A unique beer half between a stout and a black IPA.

The pour is nearly black with a moderately full, tan, dense, creamy head which is somewhat lasting and leaves scattered, frothy lace.  The nose is lots of bitter chocolate, lighter dark roast, burnt caramel, faint campfire smoke, some cedar, but also light grapefruit, resins, and faint tropical fruit.  The flavor carries more of the Simcoe and Columbus hop notes than the nose; lighter bitter chocolate and burnt caramel, still a touch of campfire, sweet grapefruit and a faint kiwi?, rustic resin, and dark coffee roast.  The palate is medium to full, creamy and velvety, drying, and soft to lively.  The beer finishes long, dry, and highly bitter, both from dark roast but also high AA hops, lingering cedar and rustic, smoky, and a grapefruit peel.  The bitterness is high especially moving towards the finish and the acidity is moderate but seemed understated.  The dry campfire and cedar notes are the only flaws I can really find in this one, they just do not meld well with the additional hops.  Other than those minor notes, the new hops add an interesting, American Black IIPA quality to the beer.  So different from the original yet shares so many similarities.  Very good experiment from a phenomenal brewery, curious to see if this will make it to beer geek brunch?

Bottle split with Pat during a "breakfast Mikkeller" flight. This was a great closer. Pours a deep brown body with nice off white lacing. Aroma is fresh hop and slight malty roast. Mouthfeel falls somewhere between a black ipa and a stout with notes of fresh hop, roasted malts, and coffee.

Poured out in the most inappropriate glassware, but still, this beer can¬ít be held down.  Pours a deep, rich, brown with frothy, deep tan color.  Aroma is of spiced chocolate, lots of floral and citrus hop spiciness mixed with chocolate and notes of roasted malt.  Taste is hop forward and very aggressive but the body on this one and the rich, dark, roast balances it out very well and makes it the most delectable treat.

Pours jet black with three fingers of thick tan head. A layer of carbonation remains throughout.

Roasted malts and piney hops are the first two aromas to hit the nose. They continue to dominate but are joined by a nice coffee undertone and a touch of sweetness.

The beer is bitter - in a good way - both from the coffee and from the hop presence. You can a lot more coffee in the taste compared to the nose. I taste dark chocolate and roasty malts as well. The finish is bitter as well. I could see how some people wouldn¬ít like the mix of hops and coffee but this works really well for me. 

The mouthfeel is smooth and creamy as you¬íd expect from an oatmeal stout. Carbonation was light but appropriate for the style. 

Overall this was a great beer that shows how talented Mikkeller is at walking the line between hops and coffee. I will buy this again if given the chance.

Bottled. The aroma has chocolate, light roast, piney and flowery hops. Black coloured beer with a lasting, beige, medium head. The taste is light sweet, with evolving bitterness. There are some light roasty coffee malts, chocolate, little fruitiness, more hopcharacter towards the finish. Very smooth, quite well balanced. Pure craftmanship.

Bottle. Black. Minimal head. Black tary oatmeal and coffee scent. Hops on the tip of the tongue and then a darker flavour. Hops seem to float on a surprisingly light stout to the back of the mouth when the hops give way to a cloudy thick stout aftertaste. I might have started it a little cold, body turns a little silkier with a light sugar edge as it warms.
Bottle.  Pours black/dark brown with a thick tan head.  Floral hops, coffee, chocolate in the aroma and flavor.  Roasted malt.  Solid brew.

16.9 oz botle from Capone¬ís.  Pours onyx with big 4-finger tan head.  Nose is huge resiny hops, pine, dark roasty malt, coffee, cacao.  Tastes very smooth, rich, with a front end of nitrogenated dark malt, incredibly velvety smooth, with mid-palate hops, coffee, cacao, and earthy molasses and blackberry and fig notes.  This one is as smooth as it gets, and absolutely wonderful.  Naysayers can suck my balls, because this one rules, and it even better than Alpha Klaus.
Black with a creamy tan head.  Floral citrus hops, cherry, and chocolate aroma.  Thick buttery palate.  Bitter coffee and bitter dark chocolate tastes with a rich earthy finish.

Bottle 16.9 oz. Split with and courtesy of James. Pours a deep brown with a thick tan bubbly head. Crazy ladder-rung lacing. amazing black floral IPA notes; dry hops, sweet malts, lavender, licorice, and bitter coffee. Full bodied with a dry roasted coffee, bitterly hoppy flavor. Some notes of vanilla and caramel. Very good stout.

16.9 oz bottle.  Dark brown with a frothy tan head.  Nose is pine and chocolate that at first seems to clash but ends up blending nicely.  Creamy body with a soft resiny buzz.  Taste is grapefruit, French roast and orange juice.  I suppose this qualifies as breakfast.  More of a black IPA with the hops dominating the chocolate and caramel notes.
Bottle. Black beer with a small brown head. Roasted hoppy aroma with vanilla, smoked notes and some perfume. Hoppy metal flavor, roasted, dark chocolate, grass and some perfume.

Opaque black color with a small, tan head that left nice lacing on the glass.  Aroma of floral hops, pine, roast, cocoa, citrus, and some vanilla bean.  Taste of roasted malts, cocoa, some smoke, citrus, pine, and a dry, roasty, bitter pine finish.
Bottle shared at a Damico beer tasting.  Pours a dark brown color with a caramel colored head.  Aroma of coffee and chocolate.  Sweet malty taste with a nice hop hit.

Bottle picked up at StateLine... Intially shared by Roberto, this bottle was consumed at home. Poured into a snifter, dark black in color, good mocha colored head. Smells hoppy! (Duh) Lots of burnt roasted malts and coffee taste. The after taste is bitter, nice and hoppy. Creamy smooth body, easy to drink. Overall: A black IPA or a hoppy stout?  Just more roasted malt and coffee... Simple but good stuff

Served from a bottle at the OTM Tasting room. The appearance is a pretty dark almost black hue with a small medium brown head. The aromas are where all the hops are. A nice citrus to earthly hop profile in the nose with a good roasted malt backing. The flavors seem to showcase the deeper malt roast profile with additions of some coffee and some oatmeal and other grains.. The mouth is pretty full boded with a heavy  feeling after taste. Probably a bitterness left from the hops. I enjoyed this one and would love to try it again.
Bottle. Pours black. Brown head. Nose and taste of oatmeal, roast chocolate malt, hops and coffee. Medium body. Nice Black IPA/Stout hybrid.

Bottle thanks to Sarah. Pours black with a brown head that dissipates slowly to the edges. Aroma has a strong pine hop note that combines interestingly with the roasted malts. Flavor starts with roasted malts and a slight dark chocolate and a growing pine note in the finish.

500ml bottle from Groppi¬ís.  Pours a black color with a big tan head and lots of lacing.  Aroma is hoppy, roasty.  A bit heavy on the palate with average carbonation.  Flavor is bitter, hoppy, roasted malt, coffee, with a bitter coffee finish.  More of an American Black Ale than a Stout for me. Meh.
Bottle (50 cl), courtesy of rlgk. Black with beige head. Rioasted chocolate aroma with coffee, green pepper, citric and perfumy hops. Medium bodied and smooth. Dry with long, firm bitter finish.

50 cl bottle, thanks to rlgk BB 1/3-2012, sampled on April 1, 2011Black color, big brown head. Very bizarry mix of hops, citrus, coffee in the scent. Not balanced though removing some elements of one kind might smooth it out to be better for me. Bitter, dry, coffee taste that finishes dry and malty. Sort of thin mouthfeel, rather high dry bitterness.

UPDATED: DEC 31, 2011 Courtesy of rlgk. Pours black as night with huge brown head leaving nice lace. Aroma is old gym shoes, hoppy, roasted malts, Peaty Mouthfeel. Flavor is peaty, fruity, slightly sweet. Medium palate. Finishes tart peaty.

Black pour topped with a substantial lasting brown foamy head.  Cirtus and coffee aroma.  Thick creamy mouthfeel strong coffee taste mixed with an initial sweetness followed by a sharp lasting bitter finish.  My second Mikkeller beer ... I think I like this guy!

Bottle from Bierkompass. Black color with thick light brown head. Aroma is coffee, apricots, hops, walnuts. Taste, definitely coffee, roasted malt, chocolate, some spices. Nice bitter finish. Nice complex beer.

500ml brown bottle. Black opaque pour. Good sized rocky, creamy head, light brown in colour, Lots of clinging lace. Hoppy citrusy notes, hints of pine and lots of coffee and chocolate in the aroma. Taste is chocolate/cocoa malt up front, citrusy middle followed by black coffee. Ends with a burst of citrus- orange, pine, grapefruit, long bitter and coffee/roasty aftertaste. Medium body, medium carboantion. Another killer Breakfast brew from Mikkeller.

28 March 2011, on tap!  really dark black, thin looking w/ thin brown lacing. really bold nose. very "stouty". burnt coffee and burnt molasses. thin body and mildly fizzy, mildly oily. really a great beer. the first time i would say i have noticed an "oatmeal" element in an oatmeal stout. roasted coffee beans, not much else. but it all goes together so perfectly!

Bottle. Poured a dark dark brown, almost black, with an averaged sized tan head. Aromas of floral hops, pine, chocolate and roast. Tastes of floral hops, chocolate, coffee, and roast. Nice fresh green floral hoppiness.

A stout with a twist. Maybe it¬ís because I¬ím sick of stouts but this had a nice twist. A nice black pour with a small tan head. The head laces down the glass. The aroma is chocolate and coffee with a very nice hop bite. The flavor is very nice like the aroma with a big hop bite. Different and welcomed for a stout.

More stout goodness. Black. Bubbles. Dark tan. messy. sticky. The big ass citrus has died off a bit, mostly being paved over by Deep roast, coffee and oatmeal yumminess. Chocolate, orange and some funky fruits that keep this unique in spots yet keep me on edge as I find citrus and coffee distracting. Interesting flavour spin with the massive coffee and hop blend. Damn thick flavour.. amazingly thick. This beast is chewy - it¬ís the only way to consume it - grind it up into tiny gelatinous globs and enjoy. The bitterness is huge - seems to come from every front - coffee, chocolate and massive hops. Oatmeal, unsweetened grapefruit - hard to really pin point these with the deluge of malt fists clubbing me into submission. The coffee harshness is almost taking over but the sweetness of the oatmeal is attempting to put up a fight. I will supply them with bananas to defend themselves. Getting more wobbly here.... Thick brew, huge roast and bitter finish. Yea, this kills a lot of beers cause it¬ís massive but at the same time, as usual, the coffee doesn¬ít quite work for me. The burning nose burp was eye watering. This new Nevermore album is decent. This is a good beer but.. yea... yea

Bottled (BB 03/2012)
Thanks tdtm82! Dark opaque black color, small brown head. Coffeish, hayish hoppy aroma. Medium-bodied. Coffeish, toasted malty with cocoa and fresh hops thrown into it. Long lingering bitterness with roasted malts. Black IPA it is!

500ml bottle purchased at wlv.  refridgerated and consumed on 3/20... pours a medium bodied dark stouty pour, predominantly opaque, and topped with a frothy light khaki head that quickly recedes leaving a soapy residue around the edges... aroma of bitter dark chocolate and a blast of piney/citrusy hops which reminds me somewhat of nightstalker.  a little roast and coffee lingering into the mix as well.  nice assertive hoppiness and overall combination of scents... flavors deviate very little from the aroma.  bitter dark chocolate, roasted grain, and coffee mesh with robust citrus and piney hoppiness while also contributing a mild degree of bitterness on the backkend.  a bitter citrus rind finish lingers for the duration and then some.  i¬ím thinking this is pretty over the top and could use some sweetness but i do generally enjoy this one.  thin to medium body, leaving a little bit of earth and chalkiness on the palate.  carbonation is present and active but not overly so. dang is this thing bitter.  a cold hop black iced coffee.

Bottle thanks to tdtm82. It pours very dark brown with a thin tan head. The nose is caramel, dark chocolate, toffee, vanilla and pine. It tastes of liquorice, charcoal, wood, burnt toast, rich-roast coffee, brown sugar, toffee, caramel, hazelnut, marshmallow, sesame seed and soy sauce. It¬ís full-bodied, oily, complex and just damn tasty.

UPDATED: MAY 5, 2015 Bottle, shared with Evin; Reakt, Scopey, Sim, Mes, T-Bone, Stuart @ The Kernel. Thanks to My Brewery Tap.

Mocha lacing, opaque black but redding out,, fantastic  hoppy notes with huge simcoe and columbus hops on aroma, coffee, choc, cream, hazlenut, vanilla,  taste is coffee roasted malt, mint choc, cream, oily, bitter, just damn good work


------  = 5th May 2015

Descent baige lacing. Chocolate and coffee on aroma. Leather and vanilla. Taste is us hops, some bitterness, nice dry hopping but not ott. A really good example of a mild but nothing else.  7/3/6/3 = WOW what a difference!!! Sorry Mikkel but this was nowhere near as good as the first batch.

Tasted 2011-03-20. Pours dark brown (almost black) with grey/brown head. Aroma is very powerful. Dominated by coffee and hops. The hops kind of tickles the nose. Taste is more coffee than hops. Strong bitterness that¬ís well rounded and reminds me more of coffee than of hops. Very tasty all the way around.

Bottle.  This shit rocks.  Tons of espresso and piney hops, great bitterness, fantastic chocolate, coffee beans, not too sweet, nice cream and sugar effect, great body, nicely attenuated with sparkling carbonation.  A winner for sure!

Pours a dark black with some light coming through. One finger of creamy light tan head. Nose shows the hop character for sure, sweet citrus rind and super green hops. Not much of the Beer Geek coming through. Too much bitterness for me, the hops on top of the dark grain and coffee is just too much. Way muddled and kind of astringent. Full bodied with a lasting bite.

Bottle from Olbutikken, Copenhagen. Shared with JoeT in Manc. Poured jet black with a healthy looking tan head and some good laceage. Fantastic nose of piney hop goodness, roasted coffee and dark choc. The flavour didn¬ít disappoint either as all of the above elements came together in a superb medley that was a pleasure to drink. The heavyweight hop bitterness works a treat and this is excellent stuff I need to get more of.

Gusher! Opened the bottle and watched as a volcano of dark brown came pouring out. Got it into the glass and a huge head of dark tan laid on top of a dark opaque brown almost black.
Hoppy! Hops on top of chocolate. Hops on top of maltiness. A sweet smell, almost caramel. It¬ís hard to smell anything else over the big hops.
Floral, grapefruit, roasty. It is much like an IIPA with some roasted malts thrown in. Very different, but very good.
Big carbonation tones down the thickness that would be present otherwise. The hops stick to the mouth with the sweet malty nectar.
Very drinkable in not so big quantities. The hops would tire the tongue if I drank more than a bottle of this in a session.
Bottle. Dark brown color with a fine head. Aroma: coffee and chocolate. Taste of hop, roasted malts and chocolate. bitter with high carbonation.

Bottle at Mikkeller Pub. Dark brown, fluffy hazelnut head, really nice! Malt, chocolate and citrus aroma, tastte is roasted, licorice, coffee and hops, bitter finish with the dry hopped grassy end. A BGB with added late hops really, want more of this one!
Nose is smoke, some dark chocolate, later almonds, bitter hops, feel is broad, carb is mediumweak, taste is sour coffee acids, some bitter chocolate, wood

Black with a big and lasting greyish brown head. Aroma is sweet, hard roated malt, light burnt, coffee and extremely hoppy, pine and grapefruit. Flavor is rather sweet and the finish is very bitter. 080111
Bottle. Black colour with a tan head. Aroma is hop, grapefruit, coffee, pine. Flavour is hop, grapefruit, coffee, alcohol, pine. Very nice beer.

(Bottle, thanks mybestfriend) Pours black with large, light brown head. The aroma is very ¬ìgreen¬î hoppy up front with tones of cat box, juicy grapefruit, blood orange, resiny pine, apricots, mint and black currant tea. The malt is medium roasted with quite dry profile of coca, coffee beans and tar. Undertones of vanilla, liquorice, bell pepper, gravel and parsley. Some light oxidation - wet dog and wet cloths. Very aromatic in the nose both from the hops and coffee. The flavour is dry, medium to heavily bitter and light to medium acidic. Coffee, roasted malt and hops blends well in the taste. Lingering citric, piny, earthy and resiny bitterness. The only downside is the light oxidation and a tiny metallic touch. The mouthfeel is clean and somewhat smooth with a medium carbonation. Medium to full bodied.

from Erzbierschof.ch - dark black coloured with a solid long lasting dark beige foam; nice lacework; roasted ans robustly hoppy with notes of cold coffee and vanilla; initially creamy mouthfeel, astringent and full-bodied; very bitter, long fruity hoppy finish with notes of licorice and almonds - a hop soup

500mL bottle.  Pours opaque black with a giant chunky tan head that settles to a persistent covering.  Strong resinous and roasted coffee aroma with subtler notes of chocolate and citrus.  Heavily roasted coffee flavour, a little chocolate, strong hop flavours, low sweetness and medium bitterness.  Medium bodied, high carbonation, reasonably creamy but also pretty floury with a lingering bitter finish.

UPDATED: MAY 1, 2014 First rating: Medium beige head. Black body. Roasty fir tree and coffee taste with resiny notes. Quite rough. Dry-bitter burnt coffee taste with oaty notes. Thinnish body. Sharp, dusty mouthfeel. Dry coarseish roasty coffee aftertaste with earthy metallic notes. Not really very successful. (0.5l bottle shared by gr0ve.) 6,4,6,2,11=2.9

Second rating: Medium brown head. Opaque black body. Strong resiny earthy pine needle aroma with mealy chocolate notes. Dryish earthy roasty coffee taste with fruity pine needle notes. Mid-bodied. Mild, mealy mouthfeel. Dry roasty sooty pine needle aftertaste with resiny earthy notes. It¬ís not bad, but a bit austere, and the hops don¬ít really add that much. (0.33l bottle, I forget where from.) 4,7,3,6,13=3.3

Bottle. Thick black pour with a rocky tan head that lasts a while. Aroma has plenty of piney hops and coffee but is very smokey as well, ashy even. Flavour pretty much mirrors the aroma. Mouthfeel is dry and surprisingly light with high carbonation and a lingering roasty, bitter finish. A little less refined than the original but still a very good stout.

(50cl bottle thanks to bu11zeye) Pours black, no highlights. Smell has coffee, fresh-cut grass, bits of wood smoke. Taste is dry and bitter and burnt. Coffee has subsumed with ash and smoke and charred wood. Very highly carbonated- I wish it wasn¬ít quite so. Bitterness really takes over on the aftertaste- strong grapefruit and lemon pith.

500 ml bottle.
